Line 192: Line 192:
====1 February â March of the Millions====
====1 February â March of the Millions====
â
[[File:Millionmarchtahrirsquare.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "March of the Millions"]]
+
[[File:Millionmarchtahrirsquare.jpg|thumb|240px|Tahrir Square during the "March of the Millions"]]
Opposition leaders called for a million-strong march dubbed '''"March of the Millions"'''<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=article in german. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended to "trans_title" field}} {{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/multimedia/bilder/kairo206.html |title=Marsch der Millionen: In Kairo marschieren die Massen gegen Mubarak|work=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|trans_title=|language=[[German language|German]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> (literally the "March of One Million", from the Arabic {{lang|ar|ÙØ³ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙÙÙÙ}} ''masÄ«rat milyÅn'') from Cairo's Tahrir Square to the [[Heliopolis Palace|Presidential Palace]] in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 1 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/01/31/3126194.htm|title=Egypt Protesters Call for Million-Man March|publisher=Abc.net.au|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='Mega Protest' Planned in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Egyptian security forces fortified Mubarak's presidential palace with coils of barbed wire to ensure that the protesters can not get there.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2011/0202/1224288768049.html|title=West Has Little To Fear from Arab Populism|author=Staunton, Denis|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Opposition leaders called for a million-strong march dubbed '''"March of the Millions"'''<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=article in german. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended to "trans_title" field}} {{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/multimedia/bilder/kairo206.html |title=Marsch der Millionen: In Kairo marschieren die Massen gegen Mubarak|work=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|trans_title=|language=[[German language|German]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> (literally the "March of One Million", from the Arabic {{lang|ar|ÙØ³ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙÙÙÙ}} ''masÄ«rat milyÅn'') from Cairo's Tahrir Square to the [[Heliopolis Palace|Presidential Palace]] in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 1 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/01/31/3126194.htm|title=Egypt Protesters Call for Million-Man March|publisher=Abc.net.au|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='Mega Protest' Planned in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Egyptian security forces fortified Mubarak's presidential palace with coils of barbed wire to ensure that the protesters can not get there.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2011/0202/1224288768049.html|title=West Has Little To Fear from Arab Populism|author=Staunton, Denis|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 204: Line 204:
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
[[File:Cairo female protesters with colorful signs - 1FEB2011.jpg|thumb|Young protesters in Cairo.]]
+
[[File:Cairo female protesters with colorful signs - 1FEB2011.jpg|thumb|240px|Young protesters in Cairo.]]
In the late evening (11:00 pm local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run for another term in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". Mubarak called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the limit terms of the presidency and change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against the parliament members which means a great amount of the parliament members will be changed through the legal process."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text – President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
In the late evening (11:00 pm local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run for another term in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". Mubarak called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the limit terms of the presidency and change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against the parliament members which means a great amount of the parliament members will be changed through the legal process."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text – President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
